title: Malltraeth Walks

images.title: Ian Warburton / Malltraeth Sands & Afon Cefni
images.caption: Malltraeth Sands & Afon Cefni. This photo shows the estuary just below Bodorgan House

images.title: Eric Jones / Malltraeth Pool
images.caption: Malltraeth Pool. This also known as the Horseshoe Pool and Llyn yr Iard.

images.title: Eric Jones / The High Street, Malltraeth
images.caption: The High Street, Malltraeth. The village began life as a camp for workers engaged in draining the marshland and maps up to the 1960s name the village as "Malltraeth Yard".

images.title: Eric Jones / Salt Marshes on the Edge of Malltraeth Sands from the Cob
images.caption: Salt Marshes on the Edge of Malltraeth Sands from the Cob

images.title: Newborough Forest by Jeff Buck, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Newborough Forest

images.title: Oliver Dixon / The beach at Newborough Warren
images.caption: The beach at Newborough Warren. This stretch of beach lies on the western side of Newborough Warren. The Malltraeth Sands (estuary of the Afon Cefni) lie in the middle distance, whilst Cwningar Bodowen is beyond.

images.title: Village Centre, Newborough by Geoff Pick, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Village Centre, Newborough

images.title: Llanddwyn Island / Ynys Llanddwyn by Ian Taylor, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Llanddwyn Island

description: This quiet Anglesey village has some stunning walking paths along the beautiful Maltreath Estuary or Cob Maltraeth. This long circular walk from the village takes you south along the River Cefni and Maltreath Sands to Newborough Forest and Llanddwyn Island. You'll then go onto visit the Newborough Warren Nature Reserve and the neighbouring village of Newborough. Start the walk in the village and then head east to cross Pont Maltreath over the river. You can then pick up a footpath heading south past the wildlife pool into the forest. Here you can enjoy miles of walking and cycling trails leading down to the coast at Llanddwyn Island where you can see the ruins of St Dwynwen's Church and the Twr Mawr lighthouse. There's also sand dunes, beaches and lots of coastal wildlife to see here. The route then heads north through the forest before heading south east to explore Newborough Warren. This section is optional and should only be attempted if the tidal conditions are appropriate. The route then visits Newborough village before heading up to the River Cefni where you can pick up a final riverside path to take you back to Maltreath.
county: Sir Ynys Mon - Isle of Anglesey
